definition[0]: to leave a place or person in a way that people disapprove of
example[0]: Amy’s husband had run off and left her with two children to bring up.
definition[1]: to quickly print several copies of something
example[1]: I’ll run off a few more copies before the meeting.
definition[2]: to force someone to leave a place
example[2]: Someone tried to run me off the road.
example[3]: Smith had run them off his property with a rifle.
definition[3]: to write a speech, poem, piece of music etc quickly and easily
example[4]: He could run off a five-page essay in an hour.
definition[5]: to get rid of weight or energy by running
example[5]: I’m trying to run off some of the calories in that chocolate cake!
definition[6]: a second competition or election that is arranged when there is no clear winner of the first one
definition[7]: rain or other liquid that flows off the land into rivers
example[6]: Can you run off a couple of copies of this report?
example[7]: It was just before Christmas and all the sales staff were run off their feet.
